study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate sulforaphane's potential as a chemoprevention agent by examining its ability to inhibit HDAC activity and modulate epigenetic alterations in cancer cells.
results_summary: Sulforaphane was found to inhibit HDAC activity in human colorectal and prostate cancer cells, suggesting its potential to target aberrant acetylation patterns and influence gene regulation. The study highlights its promise alongside other dietary HDAC inhibitors for cancer chemoprevention.
population_specificity: Human colorectal and prostate cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydroalcoholic sumac extract could mitigate oxidative stress and lung damage caused by X-ray radiation in rats.
results_summary: The study found that sumac extract, at doses of 100 and 400 mg/kg, improved lung damage and reduced oxidative stress in rats exposed to X-ray radiation, with effects comparable to vitamin C.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to X-ray radiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sumac, thyme, and cumin extracts on apoptosis and paraptosis in HepG2 cells, and their potential impact on hepatocellular carcinoma treatment.
results_summary: Sumac extract showed higher expression of caspase-3 protein compared to thyme and cumin. Sumac and thyme had an additive effect, sumac and cumin had a synergistic effect, and all three extracts together also showed synergy in inducing apoptosis in HepG2 cells.
population_specificity: HepG2 cell line (human liver cancer cells)
effective_dosage: Single, double, and triple combined doses (specific amounts not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sumac capsules could reduce postpartum bleeding in women at risk of excessive bleeding.
results_summary: The sumac group showed significantly lower mean bleeding volumes at all measured time points (1-4 hours postpartum) compared to the placebo group, with a notably lower total bleeding volume in the first four hours (215.78 cc vs. 261.51 cc, p < 0.001).
population_specificity: 72 women referred for vaginal delivery at a hospital in Torbat Heydariyeh, Iran (65 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Two 500 mg oral capsules immediately after placental expulsion and two hours later.
study_duration: 4 hours (measurements taken at 1, 2, 3, and 4 hours postpartum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of sumac extract as an active ingredient in nanofiber mats for antimicrobial and antioxidant applications.
results_summary: The study found that nanofibers containing 4% sumac extract exhibited significant antioxidant activity (up to 68.75% DPPH inhibition) and antimicrobial effects against Staphylococcus aureus (10 mm inhibition zone). The 50:50 polymer ratio with 4% sumac extract was identified as the optimal formulation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 2% and 4% (w/v) sumac extract in nanofiber mats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined potential of sumac and bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells in mitigating methotrexate-induced kidney damage in rats.
results_summary: The study found that sumac liposomes, when coadministered with BMMSCs, significantly reduced oxidative stress, inflammation, and renal damage markers while modulating key genes involved in nephrotoxicity. The treatment also improved histopathological outcomes and regulated apoptotic and antioxidant pathways.
population_specificity: Rats with methotrexate-induced nephrotoxicity.
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg of sumac liposomes (intraperitoneal, daily) alongside methotrexate (300 µg/kg every 14 days).
study_duration: Daily sumac administration alongside methotrexate dosing over 14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of sumac supplementation on cardiovascular risk factors in adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Sumac consumption significantly improved multiple cardiovascular risk factors, including reductions in fasting blood glucose, hemoglobin A1c, triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, BMI, weight, waist circumference, and diastolic blood pressure, while increasing HDL cholesterol levels. The overall results suggest protective and therapeutic effects of sumac on cardiovascular health.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of sumac supplementation on biochemical and anthropometric measurements in overweight or obese patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in anthropometric and biochemical indices (e.g., weight, BMI, cholesterol, blood sugar) within the sumac group compared to baseline, but no significant differences were observed between the sumac and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidative and antibacterial properties of aqueous sumac extract against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) through in-vitro and in-vivo studies.
results_summary: Sumac extract demonstrated strong antioxidant properties and antibacterial effects against MRSA, inhibiting biofilm formation and reducing bacterial counts in mice. It was effective at concentrations above the MIC (125-1000 µg/ml) and showed sensitivity to erythromycin and penicillin but resistance to other antibiotics.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with Staphylococcus aureus infections and mice injected with MRSA.
effective_dosage: 1000 mg/ml (antioxidant testing); 125-1000 µg/ml (MIC range for antibacterial testing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Sumac consumption on inflammation and oxidative stress biomarkers through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Sumac showed a significant reduction in oxidative stress markers (MDA) and increased antioxidant capacity (TAC, PON1) in most studies, but effects on inflammation (TNF-α, IL-6, hs-CRP) were inconsistent or minimal.
population_specificity: Diabetes patients, individuals with fatty liver, overweight individuals with depression, and those with polycystic ovary or metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the preventive effects and mechanisms of Chinese sumac fruit extract on hyperuricemia and uric acid nephropathy in mice.
results_summary: The study found that Chinese sumac fruit extract significantly reduced uric acid levels (by 39.56% in the high-dose group), protected against kidney damage, and improved oxidative stress and inflammation markers. It achieved these effects by decreasing uric acid production, enhancing excretion, and modulating related protein expressions.
population_specificity: Hyperuricemia mice fed a high-purine yeast diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sumac supplementation on lipid profile, including total cholesterol, LDL-C, HDL-C, and triglycerides.
results_summary: Sumac significantly reduced total cholesterol, LDL-C, and triglycerides while increasing HDL-C. Longer interventions (>12 weeks) and doses below 3 g/day showed greater effects on lipid parameters.
population_specificity: Adult individuals consuming sumac in various forms.
effective_dosage: Doses below 3 g/day showed greater effects on TC and LDL-C.
study_duration: Studies ranged in duration, with ≥12 weeks showing more favorable outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of sumac supplementation on markers of metabolic syndrome (MetS) in adults with this condition.
results_summary: Sumac supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure but did not affect anthropometric indices or diastolic blood pressure. The study found no changes in other MetS markers beyond blood pressure reduction.
population_specificity: 47 adults with metabolic syndrome (mean age 58.7 years, mean weight 79.9 kg).
study_duration: 6 weeks per phase with a 2-week washout between phases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of different concentrations of sumac extract (SE) on dentine micro-hardness compared to grape seed extract (GSE).
results_summary: The study found that sumac extract's efficacy was inversely related to its concentration, with higher concentrations (20%) showing less effectiveness. Neither GSE nor SE significantly affected dentine micro-hardness after 35 days of pH cycling, though GSE 5% and SE 20% showed a significant difference in pairwise comparison.
population_specificity: Dentine samples from 30 premolars (divided into buccal and lingual segments).
effective_dosage: 5%, 10%, and 20% SE solutions, applied twice daily during pH cycling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of sumac powder on clinical symptoms and laboratory parameters in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Sumac powder significantly reduced hs-CRP levels, blood glucose, and lipid profiles while increasing insulin sensitivity and HDL levels in women with PCOS. It had no significant effect on anthropometric parameters or sex hormones.
population_specificity: 88 women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
effective_dosage: 3 capsules daily, each containing 1 g of sumac powder

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the ethanol extract of Chinese sumac fruits could alleviate monosodium urate-induced gouty arthritis in rats by modulating inflammatory pathways and oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that the extract effectively prevented gouty arthritis in rats by inhibiting inflammatory responses (via NLRP3, NF-κB, and MAPK pathways) and improving oxidative stress markers (reducing malondialdehyde and myeloperoxidase, increasing superoxide dismutase and glutathione).
population_specificity: Rats with monosodium urate-induced gouty arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a diet containing sumac and pomegranate juice could improve COVID-19 symptoms in outpatients receiving standard treatment.
results_summary: The study found that consumption of sumac and pomegranate juice alongside standard treatment significantly reduced COVID-19 symptoms, including fever, cough, weakness, and gastrointestinal issues, compared to standard treatment alone.
population_specificity: 182 outpatients with COVID-19

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of sumac fruit on serum lipids and BMI in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Sumac consumption significantly changed LDL levels over time, but no significant differences were observed in TG, CHOL, HDL, or BMI between groups. The changes in BMI and serum lipids were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cytotoxic, antioxidant, and apoptotic effects of copper nanoparticles shelled with sumac on liver tumor cells (Huh-7) compared to normal kidney epithelial cells (VERO).
results_summary: Sumac-shelled copper nanoparticles showed low IC50 on Huh-7 cells, non-toxic effects on VERO cells, increased antioxidant activities, and enhanced apoptotic efficiency. However, turmeric-shelled nanoparticles had a more advanced effect than sumac.
population_specificity: Liver tumor cell line (Huh-7) and normal kidney epithelial cell line (VERO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of Sumac (Rhus coriaria) methanolic extract on secondary hydatid cyst development in mice and its effects on gene expression related to parasite development.
results_summary: Sumac significantly reduced the volume and weight of hydatid cysts compared to controls and decreased the expression of four out of five target genes (cdk6, b-raf, fgfr, ras). No significant difference was found for cdk2 expression.
population_specificity: Mice intraperitoneally inoculated with protoscoleces to model cystic echinococcosis (CE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of sumac supplementation on insulin resistance, inflammation, oxidative stress, and antioxidant markers in adults with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: Sumac supplementation marginally improved catalase activity and increased serum total antioxidant capacity (TAC) and superoxide dismutase activity, though these changes were not statistically significant. It did not significantly affect insulin resistance, inflammation, or oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Adults with metabolic syndrome (mean age 58.7 years, 80.9% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a hydrolysable tannin from Sumac (C55H40O34) could inhibit glycation markers and exhibit neuroprotective effects under high glucose conditions.
results_summary: The study found that C55H40O34 inhibited glycation markers (AGEs, dityrosine, N'-formylkynurenine, and kynurenine) in bovine serum albumin and showed neuroprotective effects in Neuro2A cells by reducing ROS formation and inflammatory markers while enhancing antioxidant enzyme expression and mitochondrial activity.
population_specificity: In vitro (bovine serum albumin and Neuro2A cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Sumac phytochemicals as antiviral agents against SARS-CoV-2 by analyzing their binding affinity and stability with the virus's main protease.
results_summary: The study found that two Sumac phytochemicals, Hinokiflavone and Myricetin, exhibited the best affinity and stability in binding to SARS-CoV-2's main protease, suggesting potential antiviral efficacy against COVID-19. These compounds also met Lipinski's rule criteria and had favorable ADMET properties, indicating good pharmacokinetic profiles.
population_specificity: In silico (computer-simulated) study, no human or animal subjects.
study_duration: Molecular dynamic simulation performed at 100 ns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sumac on cardiometabolic risk factors in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS) and related disorders through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Sumac intake significantly decreased fasting blood sugar, insulin levels, and insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), but had no significant impact on weight, BMI, blood lipids, blood pressure, or liver enzymes. The findings suggest potential benefits for glycemic control, though high heterogeneity warrants cautious interpretation.
population_specificity: Adults with metabolic syndrome or related disorders (526 participants across 9 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different levels of Sumac seed powder (SSP) on broiler chickens' performance, blood parameters, immune system, and ileal microorganisms.
results_summary: SSP supplementation (especially at 0.10%) reduced serum total cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol while increasing HDL-cholesterol, and lowered E. coli count in ileal content, but had no significant effects on body weight, feed intake, carcass characteristics, or most blood parameters.
population_specificity: One-day-old male broiler chickens (Ross 308).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the phytochemical properties, antioxidant capacities, and therapeutic benefits of Sumac, focusing on its potential for drug discovery.
results_summary: The study found that Sumac has potent antioxidant properties and demonstrates antibacterial, antinociceptive, antidiabetic, cardioprotective, neuroprotective, and anticancer effects, with low toxicity and high safety for human consumption.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of sumac powder supplementation on hepatic fibrosis and metabolic markers in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Sumac supplementation significantly reduced hepatic fibrosis, liver enzymes, fasting blood sugar, serum insulin, HbA1c, insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), oxidative stress (MDA), and inflammation (hs-CRP), while improving insulin sensitivity (QUICKI) compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with NAFLD (n=84, 80 completed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Sumac consumption on cardiovascular and metabolic parameters through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Sumac significantly improved lipid profiles (reducing LDL and triglycerides, increasing HDL), lowered fasting blood glucose, insulin levels, and HOMA-IR, and reduced total cholesterol when taken for ≥12 weeks.
population_specificity: 1,225 participants across 16 randomized controlled trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Varied, with significant effects on total cholesterol observed at ≥12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing scientific studies on Sumac to assess its potential effectiveness in treating COVID-19 infection.
results_summary: The study found that Sumac contains beneficial phytochemicals like tannins, polyphenols, and flavonoids, and demonstrated antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antiviral, and antimicrobial properties. It suggested Sumac could be useful in treating COVID-19 based on its known effects, but direct clinical evidence was not provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sumac, as a dietary supplement, could reduce fat content and improve disease responsiveness in broiler chickens while maintaining growth.
results_summary: Sumac supplementation reduced feed intake and body weight at higher doses, decreased abdominal fat by 62%, lowered blood glucose, and improved antibody titers to Newcastle disease and influenza. However, it also reduced high-density lipoproteins in blood.
population_specificity: Male Ross broiler chicks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the oncostatic (cancer-inhibiting) activities of Rhus coriaria L. (sumac) using animal models and breast carcinoma cell lines.
results_summary: Sumac significantly reduced tumor volume (27%), mitotic activity (36.5-51%), and tumor incidence (20-29%) in rodent models, with dose-dependent effects on molecular markers and epigenetic alterations. In vitro studies confirmed anticancer efficacy in breast cancer cell lines.
population_specificity: Rodent models (rats and mice) and breast carcinoma cell lines (MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231).
effective_dosage: 0.1% (low dose) and 1% (high dose) w/w in diet.
study_duration: Duration of the experiment (specific length not stated in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the phytochemical and biological benefits of Rhus coriaria (Sumac), focusing on its medicinal, nutritional, and industrial applications.
results_summary: Sumac demonstrated antibacterial, antifungal, and antioxidant properties, making it useful as a food preservative, natural additive, and in other industrial applications. Its phytochemical components were highlighted for their health and economic benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (general applications in food and industry).

study_goal: The researchers reviewed the prevalence, clinical features, and treatment options for allergic contact dermatitis caused by poison sumac and related plants.
results_summary: The study found that poison sumac is a common cause of allergic contact dermatitis in North America, with 50-75% of the US adult population sensitive to it. Current treatments are insufficient, and complete avoidance remains the only effective method.
population_specificity: US adult population clinically sensitive to poison ivy, oak, and sumac.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Rhus coriaria (sumac) on intestinal damage in a rat model of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), focusing on its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, immunomodulatory, and anti-apoptotic properties.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that sumac reduced intestinal tissue damage in the NEC rat model by exhibiting anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, immunomodulatory, and anti-apoptotic effects, suggesting its potential as a treatment for preventing NEC-related injury.
population_specificity: Newborn rat pups in a necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing findings on the effect of Rhus Coriaria (Sumac) on lipid profiles, focusing on randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The systematic review suggested Sumac positively affects lipid indices, increasing Apo A-I and HDL while decreasing Apo B, total cholesterol, LDL, and triglycerides. However, meta-analysis of three studies showed no significant difference between intervention and control groups for these markers.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with focus on lipid profile effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cytotoxic and apoptotic effects of silver nanoparticles synthesized from sumac fruit extract (AgSu/NPs) on human breast cancer cells (MCF-7).
results_summary: AgSu/NPs demonstrated a concentration-dependent inhibitory effect on MCF-7 cell viability (IC50 of ∼10 µmol/48 h) and induced apoptosis via up-regulation of Bax and down-regulation of Bcl-2. The findings suggest potential applications in cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cells (MCF-7) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to design, formulate, and evaluate a gel containing Sumac and other herbal extracts for treating recurrent herpes labialis by shortening recovery time and controlling viral protein formation.
results_summary: The study found that the gel formulation (F11) with Sumac and other herbs exhibited high mucoadhesion, controlled drug release, and good physicochemical properties, making it effective for treating herpes labialis. F11 showed slower drug release and higher viscosity compared to other formulations.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether sumac fruit extract (Rhus coriaria L.) could reduce the expression of IL-18 and IL-1β genes in articular joints, potentially offering anti-inflammatory benefits for osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that sumac fruit extract reduced the expression of IL-18 by 33.61% and IL-1β by 29.01% in LPS-stimulated synoviocyte cells, demonstrating anti-inflammatory effects. The results suggest sumac may be effective in reducing pain associated with osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: Synoviocyte cells from the joint and fluid of an 8-month-old Holstein healthy calf.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sumac hydro-alcoholic extract (SE) combined with chitosan coating and Zataria multiflora essential oil (ZEO) on extending beef shelf-life by assessing microbial, chemical, and sensory quality during refrigerated storage.
results_summary: Sumac extract (4.00%) significantly reduced microbial counts (e.g., total viable counts, Enterobacteriaceae, lactic acid bacteria) and improved sensory attributes, demonstrating effective bio-preservative properties in beef. Chitosan coating enriched with ZEO further enhanced antimicrobial effects and sensory scores, except for flavor.
population_specificity: Beef samples stored under refrigeration.
study_duration: Duration of refrigerated storage (specific length not stated in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sumac (Rhus coriaria L.) could improve cardiovascular health by affecting blood pressure, flow-mediated dilation, BMI, and serum lipid and fasting blood sugar levels in individuals with hyperlipidemia.
results_summary: Sumac significantly reduced BMI, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and total cholesterol while improving flow-mediated dilation, but did not significantly affect triglyceride levels.
population_specificity: Adults with mild to moderate dyslipidemia (elevated total cholesterol ≥ 6.0 mmol/L or triglycerides ≥ 1.7 mmol/L and ≤ 5.0 mmol/L).
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, followed by a 2-week washout period, then another 4-week intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sumac seed powder on egg yolk fatty acid composition and cholesterol levels in laying hens.
results_summary: Sumac supplementation reduced yolk and blood cholesterol levels and positively affected HDL and LDL levels, though fatty acid composition remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 63 ATAK-S laying hens (25 weeks old, average weight 1470 g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the lipid-lowering effect of sumac in patients with hyperlipidemia through a double-blind randomized controlled trial.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, or triglyceride levels between the sumac and placebo groups. However, sumac supplementation significantly increased mean serum HDL cholesterol levels after two months.
population_specificity: Patients with hyperlipidemia according to NCEP-ATP III criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the healing and protective effects of lyophilized Sumac extract against streptozotocin-induced diabetic complications in rats.
results_summary: The Sumac extract significantly reduced blood glucose levels (31% average), balanced lipid profiles, and improved hepatic and renal damage biomarkers in diabetic rats. It also restored antioxidant defense systems and reduced malondialdehyde levels.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats (6 groups of 7 rats each).
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg, 250 mg/kg, and 500 mg/kg of Sumac extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemical composition of sumac extracts and their ability to inhibit Botrytis cinerea-induced rot in table grapes.
results_summary: The concentrated sumac extract from fruits (SUF-C) showed the highest anthocyanin content, and sumac leaf extracts significantly reduced Botrytis rot development, though less effectively than pomegranate peel extract.
population_specificity: Artificially inoculated table grapes (cv. Italia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Rhus coriaria (Sumac) could reduce diabetic complications and oxidative stress in alloxan-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: Sumac extract significantly reduced blood glucose and malondialdehyde levels while increasing catalase activity in liver and kidney tissues, suggesting antioxidant and antidiabetic effects.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats (n=30, divided into 5 groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Rhus coriaria (Sumac) seed extract on reproductive system parameters in type-2 diabetic mice.
results_summary: The hydro-alcoholic extract of R. coriaria seeds (400 mg/kg) significantly improved body and testicular weight, sperm count and viability, and hormone levels in diabetic mice, demonstrating anti-infertility effects. Glibenclamide also showed positive effects, but the extract was effective at the higher dose.
population_specificity: Male Naval Medical Research Institute mice with nicotinamide-streptozotocin-induced type-2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sumac on serum glycemic status, apolipoprotein levels (apoB, apoA-I), and total antioxidant capacity (TAC) in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: Sumac significantly reduced serum glucose, HbA1c, and apoB levels while increasing apoA-I and TAC. There were significant differences in HbA1c and TAC between the sumac and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients (n=41, sumac group=22, placebo=19)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of sumac powder on insulin resistance, oxidative stress markers (MDA, PON1), and inflammation (hs-CRP) in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: Sumac significantly increased PON1 activity and decreased insulin, HOMA-IR, MDA, and hs-CRP levels, suggesting benefits for cardiovascular risk reduction in diabetic patients. Significant differences were observed between sumac and placebo groups for MDA and PON1.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients (n=41).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of staghorn sumac as a functional food or nutraceutical, particularly its antioxidant properties and inhibitory effects on cancer cells, as well as its synergistic interactions with raspberry.
results_summary: Mixing sumac and raspberry extracts significantly increased antioxidant capacities and showed maximal inhibition of cancer cell growth while exhibiting relatively low cytotoxicity toward normal cells compared to individual treatments. However, sumac alone showed cytotoxicity in normal cell cultures, raising concerns for its use as a dietary antioxidant supplement.
population_specificity: In vitro study involving rat colon and human breast cancer cells, as well as normal rat colon and human breast epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antioxidant effects of sumac leaf extracts (hydrolysable tannins) and grape seed extracts (condensed tannins) on erythrocyte oxidative damage.
results_summary: Sumac leaf extracts effectively reduced hemolysis and oxidative damage (glutathione, lipid, and hemoglobin oxidation) in erythrocytes, comparable to grape seed extracts. Sumac extracts also more profoundly stabilized erythrocyte membranes and reduced membrane fluidity compared to grape seed extracts.
population_specificity: Erythrocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hypolipidemic and protective effects of sumac fruit extract in high cholesterol diet-fed rats.
results_summary: Sumac fruit extract significantly reduced elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels, reversed hypertrophic cardiac histology, and showed no acute toxicity in rats. The extract demonstrated cardioprotective and hepatoprotective effects in hypercholesterolemic conditions.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats fed a high cholesterol diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the radical-scavenging effects of Galla Rhois extract (GRE) in vitro and investigate its neuroprotective effects, optimal dosage, mechanisms, and therapeutic time window in a rat model of stroke.
results_summary: GRE exhibited potent, dose-dependent radical-scavenging effects and reduced brain infarct volume by 37.5% in a rat stroke model. It improved sensory motor function and reduced lipid-peroxidation but did not inhibit brain edema, with protective effects only observed in pre- and co-treatment, not post-treatment.
population_specificity: Transient focal cerebral ischemia rat model (two hours of occlusion followed by 22 hours of reperfusion).
study_duration: 24 hours (two hours of occlusion followed by 22 hours of reperfusion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the epidemiology, identification, immunochemistry, pathophysiology, clinical features, treatment, and prevention of Toxicodendron dermatitis caused by poison sumac and related species.
results_summary: The study highlights the significant hazard of Toxicodendron dermatitis in outdoor occupations and activities, emphasizing recent research in prevention and providing resources for plant identification.
population_specificity: Outdoor workers (e.g., agriculture, forestry) and outdoor enthusiasts in North America.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tannin extracted from Sumac could inhibit vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) migration, potentially offering atheroprotective effects.
results_summary: The study found a significant 62% reduction in VSMC migration with tannin treatment, without evidence of toxicity or cell death. The results suggest Sumac tannin has potent antimigratory activity, supporting its potential for atherosclerosis prevention or treatment.
population_specificity: Cultured rat carotid vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs)
effective_dosage: Different concentrations of tannin (specific amounts not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antimicrobial efficacy of sumac water extracts against nalidixic acid-resistant Salmonella Typhimurium on tomatoes.
results_summary: Sumac extracts (1%, 3%, and 4%) significantly reduced S. Typhimurium populations compared to the control, with the highest reduction (2.38 log units) achieved at 4% concentration. No significant differences were observed between washing times or concentrations in effectiveness.
population_specificity: Inoculated tomatoes (Salmonella Typhimurium ATCC 13311).

study_goal: The researchers were examining the allergic reactions caused by Sumac and its management, not its safety or efficacy for human consumption.
results_summary: The study found that Sumac can cause allergic contact dermatitis, ranging from mild to severe reactions, and outlined initial management strategies including cleansing, cold compresses, and corticosteroids. Prevention involves avoiding contact and washing exposed skin promptly.
population_specificity: People who work or exercise outdoors, particularly those exposed to Sumac.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Sumac consumption on blood pressure, glycemic indices, and anthropometric measures through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Sumac significantly reduced diastolic blood pressure, fasting blood glucose, insulin, Hemoglobin A1c, HOMA-IR, and waist-to-hip ratio, but had no significant effect on weight, BMI, or waist circumference. Higher doses or longer durations showed more pronounced benefits on FBG, HOMA-IR, and WHR.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of RCTs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of sumac supplementation on glycemic indices through a systematic review and meta-analysis of clinical trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effects of sumac supplementation on fasting blood glucose or other glycemic indices, with inconclusive results on some measures. The study included six clinical trials with a total of 278 participants.
population_specificity: Not specified beyond "participants" in clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sumac on anthropometric indices, oxidative stress, inflammation, and depression in overweight or obese depressed women.
results_summary: Sumac significantly reduced weight, BMI, body fat, visceral fat, waist and hip circumference, and malondialdehyde levels compared to placebo. It also decreased interleukin-6 and tumor necrosis factor-α levels, though not significantly, while high-sensitivity C-reactive protein and depression scores improved in both groups without significant differences.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese women aged 20-65 years with mild to moderate depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cognitive improvement effects of sunflower oil fortified with sunflower lecithin, vitamin D, and vitamin A on scopolamine-induced cognitive dysfunction in mice and explore the underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that sunflower lecithin and vitamin D significantly improved exploratory behavior, working memory, and spatial memory in mice, reduced inflammatory markers and oxidative stress, and upregulated key gene expression in pathways related to learning and memory. The effects were enhanced when vitamin A was combined with these treatments.
population_specificity: Mice with scopolamine-induced cognitive dysfunction

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ultrasound treatment on bleaching clay's adsorption capacity and optimize the bleaching process for sunflower oil using machine learning models.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound-treated bleaching clay significantly improved adsorption capacity, reducing bleaching clay consumption by approximately 60% for sunflower oil. The XGBoost model outperformed traditional methods in predicting outcomes, enhancing treatment efficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on bleaching clay and oil samples).
effective_dosage: Not specified (ultrasonic power and treatment time varied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different oxidation levels of sunflower oil affect emulsion stability and gel properties in emulsified chicken meat products.
results_summary: Mildly oxidized (20 min) sunflower oil improved emulsion gelation, increasing elastic modulus and water distribution, while highly oxidized (60 min) oil caused protein aggregation, larger emulsion particles, and reduced hardness and chewiness.
population_specificity: Emulsified chicken gels (in vitro study, no human participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (oxidation levels: 0, 20, 40, and 60 min at 120°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of heating rate and feedstock composition, including sunflower oil, on the phase repartition of hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL) products.
results_summary: The study found that higher heating rates generally increased biocrude yields and energy recovery, with sunflower oil showing interactions in mixtures, particularly with carbohydrates and proteins. The most significant deviations in yields were observed in cellulose-albumin mixtures.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study using model compounds).
interactions: Interactions noted in mixtures with carbohydrates and proteins.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of ozonated sunflower oil as an adjuvant in treating cutaneous leishmaniasis caused by *Leishmania amazonensis* when combined with meglumine antimoniate.
results_summary: The group treated with ozonated sunflower oil plus meglumine antimoniate showed significant improvement in lesion thickness and parasitic burden, demonstrating enhanced leishmanicidal activity and immunomodulatory effects compared to the untreated group.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice infected with *Leishmania amazonensis*.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an electrocoagulation-integrated membrane bioreactor (EC-MBR) in treating sunflower oil refinery wastewater, focusing on treatment performance, activated sludge characteristics, and membrane fouling.
results_summary: The EC-MBR system showed higher COD and oil/grease removal efficiency compared to standard MBR, with excellent turbidity removal (>99%). However, it had a higher membrane fouling rate due to increased MLSS, altered carbohydrate/protein ratios, and smaller particle sizes. The system was energy-efficient and cost-effective for wastewater management.
population_specificity: Sunflower oil refinery wastewater

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ozonated sunflower oil (OSO) could alleviate atopic dermatitis (AD)-like symptoms and immune responses in a mouse model.
results_summary: OSO significantly reduced AD-like symptoms, inflammatory markers (IL-1β, TNF-α, NO, IgE), and immune cell infiltration while inhibiting the IL-4/STAT3/MAPK pathway and NF-κB expression, suggesting anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: Hairless mice with oxazolone-induced AD-like skin symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sunflower oil inclusion in lamb diets on in vitro short-chain fatty acid production, gas production, and in vivo growth performance.
results_summary: The inclusion of sunflower oil showed no statistically significant effect on total SCFAs, acetate to propionate ratio, methane, or carbon dioxide production. It also did not significantly impact lamb growth performance, though the small sample size may have limited detection of effects.
population_specificity: Merino lambs
effective_dosage: 480 g/day per head (concentrate diet, including sunflower oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of ozonated sunflower oil (OSO) and regular sunflower oil (SO) on wound healing, tissue regeneration, hepatic inflammation, and blood lipid profile in zebrafish impaired by carboxymethyllysine (CML) toxicity.
results_summary: OSO demonstrated superior wound healing, tissue regeneration, and hepatoprotection compared to SO, reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and dyslipidemia while improving survivability in zebrafish.
population_specificity: Zebrafish impaired by CML toxicity.
effective_dosage: OSO and SO at final 2% concentration (1 μL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the susceptibility of *Pythium insidiosum* to ozonized sunflower oil (OSO) and assess its morphological effects on hyphae.
results_summary: OSO demonstrated strong oomicidal activity with lower MIC and MOC values compared to non-ozonated sunflower oil (SO), fully inhibiting *P. insidiosum* growth in kunkers. SEM analysis revealed significant hyphal damage, particularly with OSO treatment.
population_specificity: *Pythium insidiosum* (oomycete pathogen) and equine pythiosis-derived kunkers.
effective_dosage: MIC range for OSO: 7000 to 437.5 mg/mL; SO: 56000 to 14000 mg/mL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the quality changes of high-oleic sunflower oil during frying of South American white shrimp, focusing on oxidation and hydrolysis products.
results_summary: The study found that prolonged frying increased oxidative deterioration (e.g., higher acid value, carbonyl value, and total oxidation) and the accumulation of aldehydes and ketones, but the proportion of oleic acid in the oil increased to 80.05% after 24 hours.
population_specificity: High-oleic sunflower oil used for frying South American white shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory effects of ozonated sunflower oil (OSO) on lipid metabolism in hypercholesterolemic zebrafish and their embryos, comparing its efficacy to regular sunflower oil (SO).
results_summary: OSO demonstrated superior protection against acute embryo death, reduced ROS production, and lowered inflammation and blood lipid levels compared to SO. Long-term OSO supplementation improved survivability and reduced hepatic inflammation and lipid levels in zebrafish fed a high-cholesterol diet.
population_specificity: Adult hypercholesterolemic zebrafish and their embryos.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ozonated sunflower oil on palatal wound healing compared to non-ozonated sunflower oil.
results_summary: Ozonated sunflower oil did not improve palatal wound healing compared to the placebo, reduced VEGF levels, and increased oxidative stress marker MDA. No significant differences in wound area were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing free gingival graft (FGG) procedures (n=28).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of SCF-CO2 co-solvent nano-encapsulated extracts from Cassia javanica L. petals in fortifying sunflower oil and improving its oxidative stability and potential anticancer properties.
results_summary: The study found that SCF-CO2 co-solvent extraction was the most effective method for retaining phenolic and flavonoid content, exhibiting superior antioxidant activity and significant anticancer effects against PC3 and MCF7 cell lines. Fortifying sunflower oil with SCF-CO2 nanoparticles reduced free fatty acids and peroxide levels, enhancing oxidative stability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on cell lines and sunflower oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health effects of sunflower oil (SO) and high oleic sunflower oil (HOSO) with olive pomace oil (OPO) on cardiometabolic risk factors in healthy and hypercholesterolemic subjects.
results_summary: Sunflower oil (SO) intervention increased apolipoprotein B (Apo B) and the Apo B/Apo A ratio, indicating potential negative effects on lipid profiles, while OPO showed benefits in reducing cholesterol-related parameters and waist circumference. No significant differences were observed between the study groups.
population_specificity: 65 normocholesterolemic and 67 moderately hypercholesterolemic subjects.
study_duration: Two 4-week intervention phases, each preceded by a 3-week run-in or washout period (total study duration: 14 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of blending sunflower oil with other vegetable oils to create a tailored blended oil that meets recommended fatty acid composition for improved health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that sunflower oil, rich in Ω-6 PUFA, is beneficial when blended with other oils (like coconut, flaxseed, or olive oil) to balance fatty acid profiles, enhance stability, and improve therapeutic protectiveness.
population_specificity: General population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunflower oil (SFO) and sesame oil (SO) on lipid profile, blood pressure, and anthropometric indices in women with NAFLD within a weight loss program.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in lipid profile for either group, but sunflower oil showed similar reductions in anthropometric indices and systolic blood pressure as sesame oil. However, sesame oil was more effective in reducing diastolic blood pressure and TC/HDL-C ratio compared to sunflower oil.
population_specificity: 60 women with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify chlorine sources in sunflower oil production and propose mitigation strategies to prevent MCPDE formation.
results_summary: The study found that oil from crop hulls and bleaching clay are major chlorine sources contributing to MCPDE formation. Using a mixture of pressed and solvent-extracted cake oil with static cooling and washed bleaching clay reduced total 3-MCPD by half.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on sunflower oil components and refining processes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the behavior of high oleic sunflower oil during deep frying of purple potatoes, assessing its oxidative stability and degradation products.
results_summary: The study found that high oleic sunflower oil exhibited moderate oxidative stability during frying, with increases in free fatty acids, polar compounds, and trans fatty acids over time. Oleic acid remained the dominant fatty acid, but polyunsaturated fatty acids decreased, and volatile aldehydes were produced.
population_specificity: Simulated fast food cooking process (no human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (oil used for 8h/day for 6 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antioxidant and cytoprotective effects of ozonated sunflower oil (OSO) versus regular sunflower oil (SO) under oxidative stress conditions.
results_summary: OSO demonstrated significantly stronger radical scavenging, ferric ion reduction, and cytoprotective effects compared to SO, improving cell viability, reducing ROS production, and enhancing embryo survivability against oxidative stressors like H2O2 and oxLDL.
population_specificity: In vitro (RAW264.7 cells, brain microglial cells) and zebrafish embryos.
effective_dosage: Varies (e.g., 1-16% for HDL experiments, 4% for embryo protection, 2% for oxLDL co-injection).
study_duration: Not specified (acute experiments, e.g., 24h for embryo survival).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunflower oil could provide neuroprotective effects against ischemic brain injury caused by transient occlusion of the middle cerebral artery in mice.
results_summary: Sunflower oil at 3 ml/kg significantly reduced brain infarct volume, edema, and lipid peroxidation after ischemia-reperfusion injury, while lower doses (0.03 ml/kg) were ineffective. Both doses preserved serum biological antioxidant potential (BAP) but did not affect serum reactive oxygen metabolites (d-ROMs).
population_specificity: Mice subjected to transient middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAo).
effective_dosage: 3 ml/kg and 0.03 ml/kg, administered intraperitoneally 48 h, 24 h, and 1 h before MCAo.
study_duration: Short-term (intervention administered over 48 hours before MCAo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunflower oil with canola and olive oils on lipid profile and fatty liver severity in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Sunflower oil did not show significant improvements in lipid profile compared to canola oil, and its effects on fatty liver severity were not highlighted as superior. The study found no significant reduction in lipid profile following sunflower oil consumption.
population_specificity: 72 women with Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS), mean age 29.31.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate alternative methods for assessing the quality of degraded sunflower oil and palm fat during deep-fat frying, focusing on viscosity and dielectric constant measurements.
results_summary: The study found that the dielectric constant, correlated with polar compound concentration, is the best method for assessing frying oil quality. Viscosity and dielectric constant showed strong temperature dependence, requiring temperature-specific measurements.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on oils, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of biodegradable chickpea flour packages on the oxidation of sunflower oil during storage.
results_summary: Chickpea flour packages (CPs) helped preserve sunflower oil's chemical quality by reducing lipid oxidation indicators (conjugated dienes and peroxide value) compared to control treatments, proving to be a promising biodegradable packaging alternative.
population_specificity: Sunflower oil samples stored in controlled conditions (25 °C, 52% relative humidity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunflower oil and flaxseed oil on coagulation score, oxidative stress, and inflammatory parameters in patients with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between sunflower oil and flaxseed oil regarding serum total antioxidant capacity (TAC) and coagulation score. However, sunflower oil did not significantly reduce serum IL-6 levels compared to flaxseed oil.
population_specificity: 60 patients with metabolic syndrome (27 completed in the sunflower oil group).

study_goal: The researchers compared the effectiveness of combined electrocoagulation (EC) + electrooxidation (EO) versus electrochemical peroxidation (ECP) in treating sunflower oil refinery wastewater.
results_summary: The combined EC + EO process removed 90-95% of organic pollutants, outperforming ECP, with optimized conditions achieving high DOC removal (90%) and lower energy consumption. The reaction followed first-order kinetics with strong validation (R² = 0.96).
population_specificity: Sunflower oil refinery wastewater
effective_dosage: Current densities of 5.69 mA cm⁻² (EC) and 11.56 mA cm⁻² (EO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the recovery of α-tocopherol and β-sitosterol from sunflower oil deodorizer distillate using modified zeolite adsorbents.
results_summary: Base-treated ZSM-5 zeolite showed the best adsorption performance, achieving high recoveries of α-tocopherol (99.20%) and β-sitosterol (97.32%). The process was economically and ecologically promising due to nutrient recycling and waste reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on adsorbent performance, not dosage).
study_duration: Not specified (optimization study, no explicit duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of supplementing lactating dairy cows' diets with sunflower oil (SFO), selenium, and vitamin E on the milk's fatty acid profile, oxidative stability, and consumer acceptability.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation improved the milk's fatty acid profile by reducing certain saturated fatty acids and increasing beneficial fatty acids like CLA, without affecting oxidative stability. Consumers preferred the color and mouthfeel of SFO-treated milk.
population_specificity: 32 Jersey dairy cows

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a five-day course of sunflower oil massage on weight gain and length of NICU stay in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that sunflower oil massage significantly increased preterm infants' weight gain and reduced their NICU stay duration compared to routine care.
population_specificity: Healthy preterm infants with a corrected gestational age of 30-36 weeks.
effective_dosage: Three sessions per day, each consisting of three consecutive five-minute stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how sunflower oil (S) affects lifespan and cause of death in male Wistar rats compared to virgin olive oil (V) and fish oil (F), and whether CoQ10 supplementation modifies these effects.
results_summary: Sunflower oil (S) was associated with higher death probability compared to virgin olive oil (V) or fish oil (F) at certain ages. CoQ10 supplementation reduced mortality linked to S diet but had no effect when combined with V or F diets. No evidence suggested sunflower oil modulated aging rates.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sunflower oil (SF) and quebracho tannin (QT) on nutrient digestibility, nitrogen utilization, and ruminal degradation kinetics in sheep diets.
results_summary: Sunflower oil did not affect nutrient digestibility or nitrogen balance but reduced the slowly degraded fraction and rate for organic matter and nitrogen. QT at 40 g/kg decreased nutrient digestibility but increased absorbed nitrogen, with mild effects when combined with SF.
population_specificity: Intact male sheep (45 ± 1.3 kg)
effective_dosage: 0, 20, and 40 g/kg of diet dry matter
interactions: Interaction observed between SF and QT on synchronization index for rumen microbial protein synthesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunflower oil (placebo) against microalgae oil (DHA) on disease activity and inflammatory markers in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Sunflower oil consumption increased levels of pro-inflammatory n-6 PUFAs (linoleic acid and arachidonic acid) in erythrocyte lipids but did not show significant improvements in RA symptoms or inflammatory markers compared to DHA supplementation.
population_specificity: Thirty-eight patients with defined rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document the adverse effects of self-injected sunflower oil, focusing on complications like inflammatory response, abscess formation, and sclerosing lipogranuloma.
results_summary: The study found that injecting sunflower oil led to severe complications, including inflammatory responses, abscess formation, and sclerosing lipogranuloma, with delayed diagnosis increasing morbidity and mortality risks.
population_specificity: A male patient who self-injected sunflower oil, with broader implications for subcultures like bodybuilders, passive homosexuals, transsexuals, and mentally ill individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the adsorption efficiency of sugar cane bagasse ash (SCBA) and Magnesol XL in regenerating the quality of used frying sunflower oil and evaluate the effect of water washing on treated oil quality.
results_summary: Frying degraded sunflower oil's physicochemical properties, but treatment with SCBA and Magnesol XL significantly improved quality. Water washing further reduced soap and total polar compounds in treated oil, with SCBA showing higher adsorption efficiency than Magnesol XL.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on sunflower oil samples)
effective_dosage: 1%, 2%, and 3% (w/v) of SCBA and Magnesol XL
study_duration: 20 hours of frying, with oil samples taken every 4 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if thermal treatment and fluorescence spectroscopy could effectively discriminate between pure extra virgin olive oil and olive oil adulterated with sunflower oil.
results_summary: The study found that synchronous fluorescence spectroscopy with a 20nm differential wavelength was optimal for detecting adulteration. The best discrimination models could identify adulteration at a 2% level, and the best quantification model had a prediction error of 1.75%.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on oil samples)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal conditions for acid activation of diatomite to maximize its bleaching efficiency in sunflower oil treatment.
results_summary: The study identified optimal conditions (acid concentration = 8.963 N, activation time = 11.9878 h, solid to liquid ratio = 221.2113 g/l) for diatomite activation, achieving a bleaching efficiency of about 99%.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (optimization of diatomite activation, not sunflower oil dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunflower oil could form effective, anticorrosive barrier films on iron through a simple thermal treatment process.
results_summary: Sunflower oil formed a highly conjugated crystalline lamellar network on iron, demonstrating superior anticorrosion performance with high coating resistance and low capacitance in hydrochloric acid solutions. The coating provided dual protection via passivation and barrier effects, maintaining stability for 80 days.
population_specificity: Iron substrates (not human or animal).
effective_dosage: Not specified (pristine sunflower oil used in a single-step thermal treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the oxidation susceptibility of cholesterol and stigmasterol within a sunflower oil lipid matrix during heating and evaluate the resulting sterol oxidation products, fatty acid profile, and vitamin E degradation.
results_summary: The study found that cholesterol and stigmasterol degraded similarly under heating, but cholesterol produced higher concentrations of oxidation products. PUFA and vitamin E degraded significantly, correlating with sterol oxidation.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunflower oil, as a carrier for essential oils, could effectively repel flies in cattle compared to untreated controls and other carriers like ethyl alcohol.
results_summary: Sunflower oil alone showed some fly-repellent effects, particularly in barn-held heifers for up to 8 hours, though essential oils mixed with sunflower oil were more effective for shorter durations (1.5–4 hours). Essential oils in sunflower oil repelled >75% of flies for 6–8 hours.
population_specificity: Holstein cattle (pastured cows and barn-held heifers).
study_duration: Effects monitored for up to 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sunflower oil in combination with other agents for soil remediation of polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) and heavy metals.
results_summary: Sunflower oil, combined with carboxymethyl chitosan and ultrasonication, achieved high removal efficiency rates for PBDEs and heavy metals (up to 99.1% for BDE209). Subsequent biodegradation treatment further reduced residual pollutants and partially restored soil microbiological functions.
population_specificity: Contaminated soil from an electronic waste site.
study_duration: Two successive washing cycles followed by 3 months of biodegradation treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the catalytic activity of calcium oxide derived from crab shell and eggshell in the transesterification of vegetable oil (including sunflower oil) for biodiesel production.
results_summary: The study found that calcined crab shell and eggshell catalysts achieved high conversions to methyl esters (83.10% and 97.75%, respectively), indicating promising viability for biodiesel production. No conversion was observed using untreated natural crab shell and eggshell.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Not applicable (single reaction conditions, no longitudinal intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness and impact of vitamin A-fortified sunflower oil produced by small- and medium-scale producers in addressing vitamin A deficiency in Tanzania.
results_summary: The intervention increased access to fortified oil for some vulnerable groups but did not significantly prevent vitamin A deficiency due to insufficient coverage. Large-scale fortification showed a significant reduction in vitamin A deficiency among children in Shinyanga.
population_specificity: Mother and child pairs from 568 households in the Manyara and Shinyanga regions of Tanzania.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of sunflower oil (n-6PUFA) on age-related alveolar bone loss and mitochondrial function in young and old rats.
results_summary: Sunflower oil (n-6PUFA) was associated with higher age-related alveolar bone loss compared to MUFA or n-3PUFA diets, likely due to impaired cellular adaptation to aging. It did not support mitochondrial turnover or antioxidant systems as effectively as other dietary fats.
population_specificity: Young (6 months old) and old (24 months old) rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of body massage with and without sunflower oil on the growth of low birth weight preterm neonates.
results_summary: Sunflower oil massage significantly increased mean weight at 1 and 2 months compared to massage alone, with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Low birth weight preterm neonates (gestational age 33-37 weeks, birth weight 1500-1999 g) admitted to NICU in Iran.
effective_dosage: Three times a day for 14 consecutive days (specific oil volume not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3 LCPUFA intake (from fish oil) compared to sunflower oil affects adipose tissue growth in infants.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between sunflower oil consumption and changes in fat mass-related anthropometric measures, though infants receiving sunflower oil had a higher skinfold ratio (triceps/subscapular) at 18 months compared to the fish oil group.
population_specificity: 154 healthy infants aged 9 to 18 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether high-oleic sunflower oil (OSO) competes with fish oil (n-3 fatty acids) in metabolic pathways and how their combined intake affects cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: OSO (8 g/day) reduced total and LDL cholesterol by about 10%, but this effect was diminished when combined with fish oil. OSO did not significantly affect glycemic or blood pressure parameters.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects (98 participants divided into five groups).
effective_dosage: 8 g/day of OSO (n-9) and varying doses of fish oil (1, 2, or 4 g/day of n-3).
interactions: Reduced efficacy of fish oil (n-3) on TAG reduction when co-ingested with OSO (n-9).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether replacing 10% of feed energy with sunflower oil (SO) or coconut oil (CO) would modify lipogenic gene expression and fat metabolism parameters in pigs.
results_summary: Sunflower oil increased total cholesterol in blood serum but did not significantly affect triglycerides or lipoprotein fractions. It altered adipose tissue fatty acid composition, increasing n-6 PUFA, and decreased expression of key lipogenic genes.
population_specificity: Pigs (17-19 kg body weight)
effective_dosage: 10% of feed energy replaced by sunflower oil

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different inoculum sources for anaerobic digestion of sunflower oil cake (SuOC) in terms of methane production and microbial community stability.
results_summary: The study found that inoculum II (flocculent biomass from a biosolids-treating reactor) achieved the highest kinetic constant for methane production. Microbial community analysis showed stability in bacterial and archaeal populations during anaerobic digestion, with Methanomicrobiales and Methanosarcinales dominating the archaeal community.
population_specificity: Industrial anaerobic digestion systems (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effects of Phyllanthus niruri leaf extract against liver damage and hyperlipidemia induced by alcohol and heated sunflower oil.
results_summary: Heated sunflower oil (ΔPUFA) combined with alcohol increased liver damage markers (AST, ALT) and lipid levels (cholesterol, triglycerides, free fatty acids), while decreasing phospholipids. P.niruri treatment mitigated these effects, showing anti-hyperlipidemic potential.
population_specificity: Male albino Wistar rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydroxytyrosol-enriched sunflower oil (HSO) improves cardiovascular disease (CVD) biomarker values compared to non-enriched sunflower oil.
results_summary: The HSO group showed significantly higher arylesterase activity and significantly lower levels of oxidized LDL and sVCAM-1 compared to the control group, suggesting potential CVD prevention benefits.
population_specificity: Twenty-two healthy volunteers.
effective_dosage: 800-1275 μg/d of HSO (45-50 mg/d of hydroxytyrosol).
study_duration: Two 3-week periods separated by a 2-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a dietary supplement containing vitamins, polypeptides, and amino acids could reduce the severity of insect bite hypersensitivity (IBH) in horses.
results_summary: Investigator-assessed symptoms worsened more in placebo-treated horses than in supplement-treated horses, suggesting a positive effect of the supplement. However, owner-assessed symptom severity showed no significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Horses with insect bite hypersensitivity (IBH).
study_duration: 30 days (placebo vs. supplement), followed by 30 days (all received supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sunflower oil, combined with marine algae, on the fatty acid profile and nutritional value of sheep milk fat.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation, especially when combined with marine algae, increased beneficial fatty acids like cis-9,trans-11 C18:2 and vaccenic acid but also led to milk fat depression and elevated trans-10 C18:1 levels, potentially impacting milk fat quality.
population_specificity: Fifty Assaf ewes in mid lactation.
effective_dosage: 25 g of sunflower oil/kg of DM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of sunflower oil (SO) supplementation, alone or combined with fish oil (FO), on the rumen bacterial community in dairy sheep to understand its role in developing healthier dairy products.
results_summary: Sunflower oil combined with fish oil induced changes in rumen bacteria populations, particularly increasing cluster IX bacteria (Quinella-like microorganisms). The study noted high interindividual variation in response to lipid supplementation, with only modest effects on specific Butyrivibrio bacteria involved in biohydrogenation.
population_specificity: Lactating dairy sheep (32 ewes in the first experiment, 5 cannulated ewes in the second experiment).
effective_dosage: 2% sunflower oil (SO) alone or combined with 1% fish oil (FO).
study_duration: 21 days for the first experiment; 0, 3, and 10 days for the second experiment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether PS-HOSO (plant sterols esterified to high oleic sunflower oil fatty acids mixed with dietary diacylglycerol) could improve metabolic parameters in a type 2 diabetes animal model.
results_summary: PS-HOSO significantly reduced total cholesterol (24%) and non-HDL cholesterol (34%), lowered body weight (7%) and epididymal fat-to-liver weight ratio (16%), and decreased plasma insulin levels (44%) compared to controls. Fasting blood glucose levels remained similar between groups.
population_specificity: Psammomys obesus (diabetes-prone gerbils) fed a high-energy diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how sunflower oil supplementation in goat diets affects milk fatty acid composition and secretion, as well as mammary metabolic pathways.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation in the low-forage diet increased milk fat content and yield, altered fatty acid concentrations (decreasing medium-chain saturated FA and increasing trans C18:1 and C18:2 isomers), but did not significantly change mammary gene expression related to lactose, protein, or lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Midlactation multiparous goats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sunflower oil supplementation on growth performance, nutrient digestibility, and carcass characteristics in partridge chicks.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation improved crude protein and fat digestibility, altered fatty acid composition in breast meat (increasing unsaturated and polyunsaturated fatty acids while decreasing saturated and monounsaturated fatty acids), but had minimal effects on overall growth performance.
population_specificity: Partridge chicks (Alectoris chukar)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sunflower oil (SO) supplementation, alone or combined with fish oil (FO), on milk nutritional value and animal performance in dairy sheep.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation, especially when combined with fish oil, significantly increased beneficial fatty acids like rumenic acid (CLA) but reduced milk yield, protein, and fat content. The combination also improved the n-6:n-3 fatty acid ratio.
population_specificity: Sixty-four Assaf ewes in mid lactation fed a high-concentrate diet.
effective_dosage: 20 g of SO/kg of diet (alone or with 10 g of FO/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunflower oil or olive oil modulates the hypolipemic effect of statins in patients with severe hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: The study found that sunflower oil consumption was associated with higher PUFA and alcohol intake compared to olive oil, but the olive oil group showed greater reductions in TC/HDL-cholesterol ratios and cardiovascular risk scores. Sunflower oil was less effective than olive oil in enhancing the hypolipemic effects of simvastatin.
population_specificity: 25 men with severe hypercholesterolemia and high cardiovascular risk (>20% ATP-III).
effective_dosage: Not specified for sunflower oil (habitual culinary use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunflower crude oil and its refinery by-products on laying hens' performance and the fatty acid composition of egg yolks.
results_summary: Sunflower crude oil improved daily feed consumption compared to acidulated soapstocks but showed no significant difference in egg production. The study found that hazelnut crude oil outperformed sunflower oil in enhancing yolk color index and Omega 3/Omega-6 fatty acid ratios.
population_specificity: 400 Nick Brown layer hens aged 36 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytotoxic activity of ozonized sunflower oil (Oleozon) on Giardia duodenalis trophozoites in vitro.
results_summary: Oleozon demonstrated potent dose- and cell density-dependent inactivation of Giardia trophozoites, achieving 100% inhibition at a specific dosage, with morphological deterioration observed via electron microscopy. The study concluded that direct chemical oxidation by Oleozon contributes to its parasitocidal effect.
population_specificity: In vitro cultivated Giardia duodenalis trophozoites.
effective_dosage: 30 microliters of Oleozon with a peroxide index value of 500 equivalent-mmol of activated oxygen per kilogram.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the genetic modifications of sunflower oil to alter its fatty acid composition and tocopherol levels, with the goal of improving oil quality for human nutrition and cardiovascular disease prevention.
results_summary: The study found that genetic mutations can significantly alter sunflower oil's fatty acid profile, increasing oleic acid (>90%) or linoleic acid (>80%), and modifying tocopherol forms, enhancing oxidative stability (10-20 times greater than conventional oil). These modifications enable the development of sunflower hybrids with improved nutritional and functional properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human nutrition focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytoprotective effects of ozonized sunflower oil (OSO) on rat gastric mucosa damaged by indomethacin and explore the role of reactive oxygen species (ROS), lipid peroxidation, and antioxidant defense mechanisms.
results_summary: OSO reduced gastric ulcer index and TBARS concentration while increasing SOD activity in gastric mucosa, demonstrating cytoprotective effects. Histological analysis confirmed these findings, suggesting OSO's benefits are mediated by antioxidant system upregulation, particularly SOD.
population_specificity: Rats with indomethacin-induced gastric damage

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fish oil and sunflower oil supplementation on milk cis-9, trans-11 CLA content in dairy cows managed on pasture versus confinement.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation, combined with fish oil, increased milk cis-9, trans-11 CLA content more effectively in pasture-fed cows than in confinement-fed cows. The confinement diet led to higher trans-10 C18:1 levels, reducing vaccenic acid and CLA concentrations.
population_specificity: Fourteen Holstein dairy cows (pasture-fed or confinement-fed).
effective_dosage: 640 g of fish oil and sunflower oil blend (1:3 wt/wt) daily, divided into two portions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effects of ozonized sunflower oil (OSO) on ethanol-induced gastric ulcers in rats and explore the role of antioxidant enzymes in these effects.
results_summary: OSO pretreatment significantly reduced gastric ulcer index and increased SOD and GSH-Px activities in rats, suggesting protective effects against ethanol-induced gastric injury, though no significant reduction in lipid peroxidation (TBARS) was observed.
population_specificity: Rats with ethanol-induced gastric ulcers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary therapy with sunflower oil supplemented with phospholipids on lipid profiles and blood pressure in hypertensive and obese patients.
results_summary: Unrefined sunflower oil with phospholipids significantly lowered diastolic blood pressure, reduced serum total cholesterol, LDL, apolipoprotein A1, apoB, and fibrinogen compared to refined sunflower oil. It was also noted as a beneficial source of polyunsaturated fatty acids and essential phospholipids for heart disease prevention.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertension and obesity.
effective_dosage: 30 grams of oil containing 10.8 grams of phospholipids daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effect of sunflower oil (SFO) and fish oil (FO) supplementation on milk conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) content in partially grazing dairy cows.
results_summary: Supplementing the diet with SFO and FO significantly increased milk cis-9, trans-11 CLA and vaccenic acid concentrations without affecting milk production, fat, or protein yields. The increase in CLA remained stable after the first week of supplementation.
population_specificity: Fourteen Holstein dairy cows, partially grazing alfalfa-based pasture.
effective_dosage: 300 g of sunflower oil per day, combined with 100 g of fish oil, mixed into the grain diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of concentrated sunflower oil as a frontline treatment for atopic dermatitis and other skin conditions involving sensitive skin.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that sunflower oil may help preserve skin functionality through relipidization and inhibition of inflammatory components, positioning it as a promising treatment for atopic dermatitis and similar conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis or other conditions presenting sensitive skin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the hypolipidemic effects of sunflower oil esters of plant sterols (SU-PS) with other supplements (fish oil, FO-PS, and olive oil) in hypercholesterolemic individuals.
results_summary: SU-PS significantly reduced LDL cholesterol compared to the control olive oil diet but was less effective than FO-PS in lowering triglycerides. It also improved the apoB/apoA ratio compared to olive oil and fish oil but had no effect on HDL cholesterol.
population_specificity: Moderately overweight, hyperlipidemic subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Cuminum cyminum (cumin) on hyperlipidaemia induced by alcohol and thermally oxidized sunflower oil.
results_summary: Thermally oxidized sunflower oil increased lipid levels and liver/kidney damage markers in rats, but cumin administration reduced these adverse effects.
population_specificity: Rats (experimental animals)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of replacing a blend of olive oil and sunflower oil with extra virgin olive oil on serum and lipoprotein levels in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The dietary exchange reduced serum total cholesterol, phospholipids, apo AII, and apo B, as well as LDL components, but did not affect HDL-cholesterol, serum Lp(a), or TBARS. The 10-year cardiovascular risk estimate decreased.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (63 ± 11 years) consuming a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: 8% of total energy intake from linoleic acid (sunflower oil component) replaced with oleic acid (extra virgin olive oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing cow diets with fish oil and sunflower oil (FSO) could enhance milk fat concentrations of cis-9, trans-11 CLA and examine the temporal changes in milk fatty acid composition.
results_summary: The FSO diet increased milk cis-9, trans-11 CLA content initially, peaking at day 5, but levels declined by day 15 and stabilized. The diet also altered other fatty acid profiles, reducing milk fat and protein content while increasing trans 18:1, trans 18:2, and omega-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: Late lactation Holstein-British Friesian cows (n=16).
effective_dosage: 45 g of oil supplement/kg of dry matter (1:2 ratio of fish oil to sunflower oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of NuSun sunflower oil on lipid and lipoprotein levels and oxidative stress compared to olive oil and an average American diet.
results_summary: The NuSun sunflower oil diet reduced total and LDL cholesterol levels compared to the average American diet and olive oil diet, but had no effect on triglycerides or oxidative stress markers. Lag time was shortest with NuSun sunflower oil, but no adverse effects on LDL oxidation were observed.
population_specificity: 31 men and women aged 25-64 with moderate hypercholesterolemia.
