effective_dosage: Experimental diets provided 30% fat, with NuSun sunflower oil contributing half of the total fat (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Each diet was consumed for 4 weeks, with a 2-week break between diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to transform sunflower oil cake into a biodegradable, water-resistant material using extrusion and chemical reduction processes.
results_summary: The study found that sunflower oil cake could be processed into a simpler matrix-fiber structure with high water resistance, enhanced by thermal treatment, and could be used to create cheap, biodegradable materials without additives.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on sunflower oil cake material properties).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a monounsaturated fat-rich diet (using high-oleic-acid sunflower oil) versus a saturated fat-rich diet on blood lipids and coagulation factors.
results_summary: The study found that the monounsaturated fat diet (sunflower oil) lowered factor VIIc, LDL cholesterol, and triglycerides compared to the saturated fat diet, with no significant differences in fibrinogen, insulin, or plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 activity. Plasma oleic acid levels significantly increased on the sunflower oil diet.
population_specificity: Nonsmoking men and women aged 35-69 with no chronic illness or medication use (15 subjects completed the study).
effective_dosage: Fat intake constituted 20.3% of total energy in the MUFA diet (specific sunflower oil dosage not detailed).
study_duration: 5 weeks per diet phase (10 weeks total for the MUFA diet in one group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high-power ultrasound treatment modifies the lipidic fraction of refined sunflower oil and assess its impact on traditional quality parameters.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound treatment increased peroxide values in sunflower oil but did not significantly alter fatty acid composition. Some off-flavor compounds were detected post-treatment, indicating minor degradation.
population_specificity: Refined sunflower oil samples (no human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Immediate post-treatment and during storage (exact storage duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatotoxic effects of thermally oxidized sunflower oil (rich in PUFA) and alcohol, and whether N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) could reverse liver damage.
results_summary: Thermally oxidized sunflower oil and alcohol caused liver damage, evidenced by altered matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), but NAC treatment effectively modulated these effects, reversing liver damage biochemically.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats
effective_dosage: Thermally oxidized sunflower oil (15%), alcohol (20%), NAC (150 mg/kg body weight)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of sunflower oil (SFO) on the fatty acid composition of beef cattle muscle, specifically its impact on conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) concentration and the n-6:n-3 fatty acid ratio.
results_summary: Increasing SFO inclusion in the diet linearly increased CLAcis-9,trans-11 and PUFA concentrations in intramuscular fat, improving the fatty acid profile from a human health perspective. The n-6:n-3 ratio was lower in animals fed grass silage or mixed silages compared to whole crop wheat silages, except at 55 g SFO/kg.
population_specificity: 105 heifers (beef cattle)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a dendrodoine analogue (DA) on hyperlipidemia induced by alcohol and thermally oxidized sunflower oil in rats.
results_summary: Thermally oxidized sunflower oil increased plasma and tissue lipid levels (cholesterol, triglycerides, phospholipids) and enzyme activity (AST, ALP, GGT) in rats, but these effects were reduced when DA was co-administered.
population_specificity: Experimental rats
effective_dosage: 15% thermally oxidized sunflower oil (15 g oil/100 g feed)
interactions: Alcohol (ethanol) was noted to interact with thermally oxidized sunflower oil to exacerbate hyperlipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how different forage levels in diets containing sunflower oil (SFO) and fish oil (FO) affect the production of trans C18:1 and conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) by mixed ruminal microbes.
results_summary: Decreasing dietary forage levels led to increased trans C18:1 and decreased CLA concentrations in effluent, with t10 C18:1 and t10c12 CLA replacing vaccenic acid (VA) and c9t11 CLA, respectively. The changes were statistically significant (P < 0.05).
population_specificity: Mixed ruminal microbes in a dual-flow continuous culture system.
effective_dosage: 2 g/100 g dry matter (DM) of sunflower oil (SFO) and 1 g/100 g DM of fish oil (FO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sunflower oil level and forage level on ruminal biohydrogenation and conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) outflow in steers.
results_summary: Increasing sunflower oil level (2% vs. 4% of DM) increased duodenal fatty acid flow but did not alter cis-9, trans-11 CLA outflow. Higher forage levels linearly increased ruminal biohydrogenation of unsaturated 18-C fatty acids and trans-11 vaccenic acid outflow.
population_specificity: Six Hereford steers (295 kg) with duodenal cannulas.
study_duration: 10-day diet adaptation periods followed by 4-day sample collection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an oleic acid-rich sunflower oil diet versus a palmitic acid-rich palmolein diet on platelet aggregation and thromboxane production in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The oleic acid-rich sunflower oil diet showed no significant increase in platelet aggregation or thromboxane production compared to the palmolein diet, which increased platelet aggregation and urine thromboxane levels. The thrombogenic ratio remained unchanged between the two diets.
population_specificity: Fourteen postmenopausal women
effective_dosage: High oleic acid sunflower oil diet (~46% energy from fat, ~400 mg/d cholesterol)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ozonized sunflower oil (Oleozon) in treating tinea pedis compared to ketoconazole cream 2%.
results_summary: Oleozon showed comparable efficacy to ketoconazole, with 75% clinical and mycological cure rates versus 81% for ketoconazole, and no significant differences between groups. No side effects, bacterial super-infections, or recurrences were observed in the Oleozon group after 6 months.
population_specificity: 200 patients with tinea pedis (100 in each treatment group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunflower oil could maintain breast-milk retinol concentrations in pregnant and lactating women compared to red palm oil and a control group.
results_summary: Sunflower oil consumption maintained breast-milk retinol concentrations similarly to red palm oil, preventing the postpartum decline observed in the control group. No significant differences in plasma retinol concentrations were found between the groups.
population_specificity: Ninety rural, pregnant Tanzanian women in their third trimester, followed postpartum.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used in household food preparations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a mixed oil diet (olive/sunflower oil) high in oleic acid with a PUFA-rich corn oil diet on human plasma and lipoprotein metabolism.
results_summary: The PUFA-rich corn oil diet significantly reduced LDL cholesterol and showed trends in lowering total cholesterol and triglycerides, while the mixed oil diet had less influence on lipoprotein metabolism. Both diets left HDL cholesterol unchanged.
population_specificity: 28 healthy, non-smoking young men aged 19-31 years.
effective_dosage: 12 g sunflower oil/day (as part of a 68 g olive oil + 12 g sunflower oil mixture).
study_duration: 2 weeks per diet, with a crossover after 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the practical use of sunflower oil for the painless removal of tar in burn patients.
results_summary: Sunflower oil was effectively used to remove tar in four burn patients, facilitating burn assessment and improving patient comfort without reported complications. The study highlights its easy accessibility from hospital kitchens.
population_specificity: Four tar burn patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different dietary oils (coconut, olive, sunflower) on fatty acid composition in plasma phospholipids, triacylglycerols, and cholesteryl esters in rats.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation increased linoleic acid content in rats compared to coconut and olive oil groups. The effects were observed within six days and mirrored longer-term study results.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of dietary sunflower oil supplementation on subclinical breast inflammation and systemic inflammation in lactating women.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation reduced milk Na/K ratio, IL-8, and TGF-beta at 3 months postpartum, with the effect being statistically significant only for Na/K ratio. The results suggest sunflower oil may improve subclinical breast inflammation, possibly due to its vitamin E content.
population_specificity: Rural Tanzanian women during late pregnancy and lactation.
study_duration: Late pregnancy and up to 3 months postpartum

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a diet high in monounsaturated enriched sunflower oil versus a low-fat diet on coronary heart disease (CHD) risk factors, including LDL oxidation, lipid profiles, glucose, and insulin levels.
results_summary: The monounsaturated enriched sunflower oil diet significantly increased HDL cholesterol, HDL3 cholesterol, insulin levels, and LDL oxidation lag phase compared to the low-fat diet, suggesting potential CHD risk reduction. No significant differences were found in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides, glucose, or LDL particle size between the two diets.
population_specificity: 14 healthy males (35-55 years) and 14 healthy postmenopausal women (50-60 years).
effective_dosage: 40-42% of energy from fat (26-28% from monounsaturated fat) in the sunflower oil diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunflower oil and rapeseed oil on lipoprotein and fatty acid composition in healthy subjects when substituted for saturated fats.
results_summary: Sunflower oil significantly decreased serum cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and apolipoprotein B concentrations, similar to rapeseed oil, while increasing 18:2 n-6 serum phospholipids and alpha-tocopherol. No adverse effects were reported, and both oils were equally effective in improving lipoprotein profiles.
population_specificity: 101 healthy subjects (mean age 29.2 years) at residential schools.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used for cooking and as table margarine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-oleic sunflower oil (HOSO) and beef tallow on tissue fatty acids, stearoyl-CoA desaturase activities, and plasma triglycerides and lipoprotein-cholesterol fractions in swine.
results_summary: The HOSO diet altered tissue fatty acid composition and reduced stearoyl-CoA desaturase activity in adipose tissue but did not significantly affect plasma lipoprotein cholesterol compared to beef tallow. Plasma triglycerides declined in tallow-fed pigs, while both fats similarly increased plasma cholesterol fractions by 4 weeks.
population_specificity: Sixteen gilts (female pigs) divided into two dietary groups.
effective_dosage: 10 g/100 g of diet (HOSO or beef tallow).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of hydrated polyuronides (e.g., alginic acid, pectic and pectinic acids) in removing heavy metals from hydrogenated vegetable oils, including sunflower oil.
results_summary: The study found that pectinic acid treatments effectively removed heavy metals from hydrogenated oils, with higher efficiency at lower concentrations of pectinic acids. Multiple treatments with pectinic acid further improved demetalization.
population_specificity: Laboratory experiments (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (degree of swelling of polyuronides ranged from 4 to 12.8 ml/g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether plasma concentrations of lipid mediators derived from EPA, DHA, and AA differ between postmenopausal women and men, using high-oleic acid sunflower oil as a placebo.
results_summary: The study found no sex differences in plasma phospholipid EPA, DHA, and AA levels at baseline or after supplementation, but postmenopausal women had lower concentrations of certain lipid mediators derived from these fatty acids compared to men, especially after supplementation.
population_specificity: Twelve postmenopausal women and 9 men with low-grade chronic inflammation.
effective_dosage: 3 g/d high-oleic acid sunflower oil (placebo phase).
study_duration: 4-week placebo phase, followed by 10-week supplementation phases (with crossover).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunflower oil (as a placebo) influenced the expression of muscle regeneration markers, T-cell populations, and disease progression markers in DMD patients compared to omega-3 LCPUFAs.
results_summary: The study found that sunflower oil (placebo) did not significantly modulate CD49d+CD8+ T-cells compared to omega-3 LCPUFAs, and no significant effects on FOXP3 expression were observed. The placebo group served primarily as a control without notable therapeutic outcomes.
population_specificity: Boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) (n=13 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ω3-LCPUFAs supplementation versus sunflower oil (placebo) on cardiometabolic and inflammatory factors in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
results_summary: The study found that sunflower oil (placebo) did not significantly improve cardiometabolic or inflammatory markers compared to ω3-LCPUFAs, which showed better outcomes in reducing triglycerides, VLDL-C, IL-6, and atherogenic index. Total cholesterol was higher in the ω3-LCPUFAs group than the placebo group.
population_specificity: Children aged 6.7 ± 2.7 years newly diagnosed with ALL.
effective_dosage: Not specified for sunflower oil (used as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of EPA, DHA, and high oleic acid sunflower oil (placebo) on monocyte gene expression in individuals with low-grade chronic inflammation.
results_summary: Sunflower oil served as a placebo and showed baseline gene expression patterns. EPA and DHA had differential effects on gene expression compared to sunflower oil, with some effects being sex-specific.
population_specificity: 16 subjects (8 men and 8 women) aged 50-75 years with low-grade chronic inflammation.
effective_dosage: 3 g/d high oleic acid sunflower oil (placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Nigella sativa oil versus sunflower oil (placebo) on endothelial function and atherogenic indices in coronary artery disease patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant reported effects of sunflower oil on endothelial function or atherogenic indices, as it was used as a placebo and showed no notable changes compared to the active treatment group.
population_specificity: 60 individuals aged 35-65 years with coronary artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunflower oil (as a placebo) against Camelina sativa oil on glucose homeostasis, inflammation, metabolic endotoxemia, and oxidative stress in NAFLD patients.
results_summary: Sunflower oil did not show significant improvements in insulin concentration, HOMA-IR, LPS, TAC, SOD, MDA, or 8-iso-PGF2α, though hs-CRP decreased in both groups. The study primarily highlighted the benefits of Camelina sativa oil over sunflower oil.
population_specificity: 46 patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Nigella sativa oil extract versus sunflower oil (placebo) on cardiometabolic risk factors in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Sunflower oil was used as a placebo and showed no significant changes in cardiometabolic risk factors compared to the Nigella sativa oil group, which demonstrated improvements in glycemic control, lipid profile, blood pressure, and body weight.
population_specificity: 43 patients with type 2 diabetes (23 women and 20 men; aged 53.5 ± 7.4 years).
effective_dosage: Two 500-mg soft gel capsules per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Nigella sativa oil supplementation versus sunflower oil (placebo) on metabolic parameters in individuals with coronary artery disease.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results for sunflower oil, only noting its use as a placebo. The study focused on Nigella sativa oil's effects, which showed significant reductions in weight and BMI.
population_specificity: 60 patients with coronary artery disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sunflower oil as a placebo compared to cholecalciferol supplementation on lipid profiles and body composition in children with hypertriacylglycerolemia.
results_summary: Sunflower oil was used as a placebo and showed no significant improvement in lipid profiles compared to the cholecalciferol group, which demonstrated reduced serum cholesterol levels. The study did not report adverse effects from sunflower oil.
population_specificity: Brazilian children aged 4-11 years with hypertriacylglycerolemia, including both eutrophic and overweight/obese individuals.
effective_dosage: Five drops daily (exact volume not specified).
study_duration: 12 weeks per intervention period (total study duration: 34 weeks with washout).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunflower oil (DP) supplementation versus LCPUFA-ω3 (DO3) on insulin resistance and weight in adolescents with obesity.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation, alongside an energy-restricted diet, showed no significant difference in body weight, insulin levels, or HOMA changes compared to LCPUFA-ω3. Both groups exhibited similar outcomes despite baseline metabolic abnormalities.
population_specificity: Adolescents with obesity (366 participants, 126 completed follow-up in the DP group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether γT-enriched capsules (compared to sunflower oil placebo) could mitigate neutrophilic airway inflammation in rats and healthy human volunteers.
results_summary: Sunflower oil was used as a placebo and showed no significant effect on reducing airway neutrophil recruitment compared to γT treatment, which significantly decreased neutrophils in both rats and humans.
population_specificity: F344/N rats and 13 nonasthmatic human volunteers.
effective_dosage: Not specified for sunflower oil (used as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the postprandial effects of different fatty meals, including a low-fat, high-complex carbohydrate meal supplemented with high oleic sunflower oil, on lipid and lipoprotein responses in patients with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that the low-fat, high-complex carbohydrate meal with sunflower oil supplement transiently increased plasma triglycerides and LDL density, similar to other tested meals. However, the adverse effects on LDL particle profile and ischemia modified albumin were not alleviated as effectively as with the n-3 PUFA supplement.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
effective_dosage: 1.24 g high oleic sunflower oil supplement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sunifiram affects NMDAR-dependent synaptic function in the hippocampal CA1 region and its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Sunifiram significantly enhanced NMDAR-dependent long-term potentiation (LTP) in mouse hippocampal slices, peaking at 10 nM, through activation of CaMKII and PKCα pathways. The effects were inhibited by glycine-binding site antagonists, suggesting Sunifiram acts via the glycine-binding site of NMDAR.
population_specificity: Mouse hippocampal slices
interactions: Inhibited by 7-chloro-kynurenic acid (7-ClKN) and PP2; no effect with ifenprodil or high glycine (300 μM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of sunlight exposure in enhancing the pesticidal and larvicidal activities of silver nanoparticles capped with copper chlorophyllin (AgNPs-CHL) against Musca domestica.
results_summary: Sunlight exposure following 24 hours of feeding AgNPs-CHL resulted in 60% mortality in adult Musca domestica and 75% mortality in larvae, demonstrating significant pesticidal and larvicidal effects.
population_specificity: Musca domestica (adults and larvae)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sunifiram improves memory impairment and depression in olfactory bulbectomized (OBX) mice, focusing on its effects on hippocampal long-term potentiation (LTP) and molecular pathways.
results_summary: Sunifiram significantly improved spatial reference memory and short-term memory in OBX mice, restored hippocampal LTP, and enhanced phosphorylation of key synaptic proteins (CaMKIIα, GluR1, PKCα, NR1). However, it did not ameliorate depressive behaviors.
population_specificity: Olfactory bulbectomized (OBX) mice with hippocampus-dependent memory impairment.
interactions: Gavestinel (NMDAR glycine-binding site inhibitor) inhibited Sunifiram's effects on CaMKII and PKC autophosphorylation.

study_goal: The researchers were not attempting to determine anything about Sunlight; the abstract discusses treatment options for metastatic colorectal cancer.
results_summary: The study did not investigate Sunlight; it focused on therapies for refractory metastatic colorectal cancer, including targeted treatments, immunotherapy, and rechallenge strategies.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic colorectal cancer, particularly those with microsatellite-stable (MSS) disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal effectiveness of Photodynamic Inactivation (PDI) using chlorophyllin-based formulations and sunlight against Penicillium digitatum in citrus fruits.
results_summary: Sunlight illumination (300 J cm-2) enhanced the eradication of P. digitatum in spore cultures and achieved complete disinfection of orange peel plugs. The treatment did not alter the antioxidant scavenging activity of the fruit.
population_specificity: In vitro fungal cultures (mycelial spheres, spores) and orange peel plugs as model systems for citrus fruit infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Cu- and Co-doped TiO2 macrocomposites for photodegrading amoxicillin (AMX) in water under solar irradiation.
results_summary: The study found that Cu (0.1%)/TiO2 and Co (0.1%)/TiO2 achieved up to 95% degradation of AMX in 3 hours at pH 5.9, with Cu-doped material showing faster reaction rates and higher total-organic-carbon removal (80.4%) compared to Co-doped (59%). The macrocomposites demonstrated efficient recyclability over five reuse cycles.
population_specificity: Water pollutants (specifically amoxicillin) in a controlled laboratory setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a novel g-C3N4/CeO2/Fe3O4 composite under simulated sunlight for photocatalytic degradation of ciprofloxacin in water.
results_summary: The ternary composite achieved 97.5% ciprofloxacin removal in 180 minutes, outperforming individual and binary components due to enhanced charge separation and light absorption. The composite also demonstrated high stability and recyclability, maintaining efficiency over five cycles, and the treated solution showed excellent biocompatibility.
population_specificity: Not applicable (environmental study on water treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a BiOBr/g-C3N4/agarose aerogel (BCA) in activating peroxymonosulfate (PMS) under simulated sunlight for degrading multi-pollutants in aquatic environments.
results_summary: The BCA/PMS/Light system demonstrated high degradation efficiency for organic contaminants, achieving a rate constant of 0.1503 min-1 for rhodamine B (RhB), outperforming control systems. The degradation mechanism involved reactive oxygen species (1O2, •O2-, •OH, SO4•-) with a dominant non-radical pathway.
population_specificity: Aquatic environments (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (simulated sunlight and PMS activation conditions described).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the chemical and nutritional changes in oca cultivars after exposure to sunlight and traditional dehydration techniques.
results_summary: Sunlight exposure improved antioxidant capacity, polyphenol and carotenoid concentrations, and sugar content while reducing oxalate levels. Dehydration preserved shelf life but reduced antioxidant capacity and polyphenols while increasing amylopectin.
population_specificity: Oca (Oxalis tuberosa) cultivars from high-altitude Andean regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Cy1280, a photosensitizer activated by mild sunlight, in improving tumor-targeted photodynamic therapy while minimizing systemic adverse effects.
results_summary: Cy1280 demonstrated prolonged tumor retention (>336 h) and effective imaging-guided solid-tumor therapy in mice, with reduced off-target phototoxicity due to albumin modulation and synergistic uptake mechanisms. Mild sunlight irradiation (100 ± 5 Klx) activated Cy1280 to induce mitochondrial protein dysfunction in tumor cells.
population_specificity: Tumor-bearing BALB/C mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a BC/MoS2/TiO2 composite film as a sunlight-excited photocatalyst for degrading organic pollutants and eliminating bacterial pathogens in industrial wastewater.
results_summary: The BC/MoS2/TiO2 composite demonstrated high photodegradation efficiencies for methylene blue and rhodamine B, as well as strong antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli under sunlight illumination, with excellent reusability over four cycles.
population_specificity: Industrial wastewater contaminants (organic dyes and bacterial pathogens).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how sunlight exposure affects the chemical composition and degradation of edible oils, focusing on the formation of harmful aldehydes.
results_summary: The study found that sunlight exposure significantly increased the formation of genotoxic and cytotoxic aldehydes in edible oils, highlighting potential health risks associated with prolonged light exposure.
population_specificity: Five widely used edible oils (olive, rapeseed, sunflower, sesame, and peanut oils).
effective_dosage: 3 and 8 hours of direct sunlight exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunlight-sensitive carbon dots (CDs) could serve as a sustainable, dual-purpose solution for plant protection by priming immune responses and acting as broad-spectrum antifungal agents.
results_summary: The study found that CDs generated reactive oxygen species (ROS) under light, triggering plant immune responses and damaging pathogen structures, leading to reduced disease incidence (e.g., 44% reduction in grey mould in N. benthamiana). CDs also showed broad-spectrum antifungal activity, with inhibition ratios up to 100% for certain pathogens.
population_specificity: Plants (N. benthamiana and tomato leaves)
effective_dosage: 240 mg/L (2 mL per plant) for disease reduction; 480 mg/L (1 mL) combined with sunlight for antifungal activity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel bionanomaterial (ZnO/CS/CMC nanocomposite) for wastewater treatment, evaluating its photocatalytic performance under sunlight irradiation.
results_summary: The nanocomposite achieved 99.5% degradation of methylene blue (MB) in 60 minutes under sunlight, with an adsorption capacity of 4.66 mg g-1, demonstrating high efficiency and synergistic effects between ZnO and the matrix.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).
effective_dosage: Molar ratio of ZnO (0.5-1.5) in the nanocomposite.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sunlight-driven photocatalysis using g-C3N4 for degrading antibiotics in biogas slurry.
results_summary: The study found that g-C3N4, particularly UCN550, effectively degraded tetracyclines (TCs) in biogas slurry under sunlight, achieving a 94.43% removal rate within 30 minutes. The catalyst showed promise for engineering applications due to its efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and performance in real wastewater.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study with no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (photocatalysis conditions: 30 minutes under sunlight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tin oxide nanoparticles (SnO2 NPs) synthesized from waste-printed circuit boards could effectively degrade dyes in wastewater under natural sunlight.
results_summary: The study found that SnO2 NPs exhibited excellent photocatalytic degradation of both cationic (methylene blue) and anionic (eosin Y) dyes under natural sunlight, with faster degradation rates for anionic dyes. The nanoparticles' small size and positive zeta potential enhanced their adsorption and degradation efficiency.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on wastewater treatment).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on nanoparticle synthesis and photocatalytic performance).
study_duration: Not specified (experimental conditions described, but no explicit duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of trifluridine/tipiracil (FTD/TPI) + bevacizumab versus FTD/TPI alone on quality of life (QoL) and Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status (ECOG PS) in patients with refractory metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
results_summary: Patients receiving FTD/TPI + bevacizumab showed no clinically relevant changes in QoL, prolonged time to definitive deterioration of QoL, and delayed ECOG PS worsening compared to FTD/TPI alone. Additionally, those with maintained ECOG PS had improved overall and progression-free survival in the combination arm.
population_specificity: Patients with refractory metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
study_duration: Assessments were conducted at baseline and on Day 1 of each treatment cycle, up to cycle 6.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sunlight-driven photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue dye using Cu2-XSe nanoparticles for water treatment.
results_summary: The study found that Cu2-XSe nanoparticles achieved 90.3% photocatalytic degradation efficiency under sunlight, with reusability demonstrated over four cycles, suggesting potential for industrial wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: Industrial wastewater and contaminated water bodies

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of polyaniline oxide (PANI) nanoparticles as photocatalysts for degrading organic dyes under simulated sunlight irradiation.
results_summary: The study found that PANI nanoparticles were highly effective in removing methylene blue (MB) dye (97.09% efficiency) but less effective for rhodamine B (RhB) (58.01% efficiency). The photocatalyst demonstrated photostability and reproducibility in recycling experiments.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using organic dyes).
effective_dosage: Not specified (photocatalytic degradation under simulated sunlight).
study_duration: Not specified (experimental conditions described, but no explicit duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photocatalytic efficiency of F-doped TiO2 composite materials under sunlight irradiation for degrading methylene blue in water.
results_summary: The study found that LiF-doped TiO2 powders, combined with vanadium and molybdenum, exhibited high photocatalytic performance under sunlight, achieving a degradation rate of 7.26 × 10⁻⁹ mol per gram of photocatalyst, outperforming commercial and undoped TiO2.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using methylene blue in water).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate impact of blue glass-filtered sunlight exposure on blood pressure and pulse rate in hypertensive individuals.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in systolic blood pressure and pulse rate in the group exposed to blue glass-filtered sunlight, with no significant changes observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 60 hypertensive patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of using concentrated sunlight with a ZnO/g-C3N4 nanocomposite photocatalyst for degrading Ciprofloxacin (CIP) in wastewater.
results_summary: The study demonstrated 100% degradation of CIP in 210 minutes under sunlight using the photocatalyst, with microbiological tests confirming the absence of antibacterial activity in treated water. The process was designed for sustainability and scalability.
population_specificity: Wastewater contaminated with Ciprofloxacin (CIP).
effective_dosage: Not specified (small-prototype scale: 10 liters/h, catalyst area 187.5 cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how UVA radiation (from sunlight or UV lamps) affects the topological and mechanical properties of DNA, both in bare and cell-encapsulated forms.
results_summary: The study found that UVA radiation causes DNA damage by forming inter-strand cross-links (CPDs and 6-4 lesions), leading to loss of DNA conformational transitions, reduced flexibility, and increased stiffness. Damage severity was dose-dependent, with cellular DNA showing higher resistance than bare DNA.
population_specificity: Single DNA molecules (bare or E. coli cell-encapsulated).
effective_dosage: UVA doses ranged from 240 kJ/m² (bare DNA) to 900 kJ/m² (cellular DNA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of an activated carbon/hydroxyapatite (AC/HAp) composite for methylene blue dye degradation and hydrogen production under sunlight.
results_summary: The AC/HAp composite achieved high methylene blue degradation rates (82.05%) and optimal hydrogen production (3579 mol/g.h) under sunlight, attributed to reduced crystallite size and enhanced light transmission. The study also demonstrated the efficacy of an IoT-enabled monitoring system for wastewater treatment and hydrogen production.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the associations of season, sunlight, and light sensitivity with depressive symptoms in people with visual impairment.
results_summary: Increased sunlight exposure was associated with lower odds of depressive symptoms, while light sensitivity was linked to higher odds. Depressive symptoms were most common in winter and least common in fall.
population_specificity: People with visual impairment (N = 1925).
effective_dosage: Not specified (sunlight exposure calculated based on weather station data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether UV light (sunlight) could trigger the reactivation of plaque morphea in a patient with a history of the condition.
results_summary: The study found that intense sunlight exposure led to the reactivation of a previously regressed plaque morphea lesion, while consistent use of photoprotective agents and avoidance of prolonged sun exposure prevented further reactivation.
population_specificity: A 61-year-old woman with histopathologically confirmed plaque morphea.
effective_dosage: Not specified (sunlight exposure described as "intense" and "prolonged").
study_duration: Observations spanned four years, with intermittent topical treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the performance and durability of pn-junction thermoelectric generators (TEGs) using sunlight by incorporating bismuth telluride (Bi2Te3) nanoplates into n-type single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) films.
results_summary: The study found that adding Bi2Te3 nanoplates to n-type SWCNT films improved the output voltage of pn-junction TEGs under uniform sunlight irradiation, with a stable output voltage of 0.47 mV observed after 1 hour of heat treatment. The output voltage decreased with longer heat treatment times due to a reduction in the p-type region.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on materials, not human subjects).
study_duration: Not specified (performance measured under artificial sunlight irradiation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of sunlight exposure (or lack thereof) on bone mineral density (BMD) in patients with erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) and evaluate factors like vitamin D supplementation and afamelanotide treatment.
results_summary: The study found that EPP patients, who avoid sunlight due to phototoxic reactions, have low BMD, with 82.7% showing suboptimal Z-scores. Vitamin D deficiency significantly increased the odds of low BMD, while cholecalciferol supplementation improved BMD, but afamelanotide did not.
population_specificity: Adult patients with erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photocatalytic activity of Alg/CuO-gC₃N₄ hydrogel beads under sunlight irradiation for degrading methylene blue (MB).
results_summary: The Alg/CuO-gC₃N₄ achieved 85.15% degradation efficiency for MB under sunlight irradiation within 60 minutes, demonstrating excellent stability and reusability. The hybrid material also reduced the bandgap, enhancing photocatalytic activity.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using methylene blue as a pollutant model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of trifluridine/tipiracil plus bevacizumab versus trifluridine/tipiracil alone in prolonging survival and delaying cancer progression in refractory metastatic colorectal cancer patients.
results_summary: The combination therapy significantly improved median survival (10.8 vs. 7.5 months), delayed cancer progression (5.6 vs. 2.4 months), and prolonged physical functioning (9.3 vs. 6.3 months) compared to monotherapy, with common side effects including neutropenia, nausea, and anemia.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic colorectal cancer refractory to no more than two prior treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a solar-driven self-cleaning composite membrane for efficient oil-water emulsion separation and anti-fouling performance.
results_summary: The composite membrane demonstrated high flux (700.6–2350.6 L∙m-2∙h-1∙bar-1), excellent separation efficiency (>99.0%), and solar-driven self-cleaning and antibacterial capabilities (≈100% efficiency). It also activated peroxomonosulfate (PMS) under sunlight for oil-fouling and dye removal.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on membrane technology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the photochemical transformation of naproxen (NPX) under UV and natural sunlight irradiation to understand its degradation pathways and photoproduct toxicity.
results_summary: The study found that NPX photolysis is significantly influenced by UV and sunlight, with photoproducts like 2A6MN acting as potent triplet sensitizers that promote further degradation. Photoproducts exhibited higher toxicity than the parent compound, as shown by bioluminescence inhibition assays.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on aqueous solutions and hospital wastewater).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of simulated sunlight in activating monochloramine for degrading environmental organic microcontaminants in water treatment.
results_summary: Simulated sunlight efficiently degraded various microcontaminants via monochloramine activation, with chlorine and hydroxyl radicals identified as major contributors. The study demonstrated strong reliability of the kinetic model, with less than 10% difference between simulated and measured degradation data.
population_specificity: Environmental water samples (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (simulated sunlight and monochloramine concentrations varied under experimental conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability and efficacy of glutamic acid-valine-citrulline linkers in antibody-drug conjugates compared to valine-citrulline linkers, particularly in mouse models.
results_summary: The study found that the glutamic acid-valine-citrulline linker showed minimal premature cleavage in mice and greater treatment efficacy in tumor models compared to the valine-citrulline variant. The linker also demonstrated high in vivo stability despite high exposure.
population_specificity: Mouse tumor models

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Valine on food intake regulation and amino acid sensing mechanisms in rainbow trout, comparing different administration routes (IP and ICV).
results_summary: Valine showed mixed effects on food intake, inducing anorexigenic responses when administered intraperitoneally but orexigenic responses when administered intracerebroventricularly. It had few effects on hypothalamic amino acid sensing systems after ICV treatment but significantly affected parameters after IP treatment, suggesting indirect mechanisms.
population_specificity: Rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether valine supplementation in a reduced protein diet affects growth performance, plasma amino acid profiles, metabolism, and endocrine/neural systems in piglets.
results_summary: Piglets with a higher Val:Lys ratio showed improved feed intake, weight gain, and feed conversion ratio, along with lower plasma urea nitrogen and altered expression of metabolic and neural markers. Plasma amino acid profiles and metabolism-related markers in serum, muscle, and liver were significantly different between treatments.
population_specificity: Piglets (with or without a precaval vein catheter)
effective_dosage: Standardized ileal digestible Val:Lys ratios of 0.45 and 0.65

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the preparation, stability, and efficacy of valine-alanine (VA)-based antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs) with valine-citrulline (VC)-based ADCs, specifically when loaded with monomethyl auristatin E (MMAE) and targeting HER2.
results_summary: The study found that VA-based ADCs performed comparably to VC-based ADCs in terms of preparation, stability, and cytotoxicity. In vivo studies showed potent anti-tumor activity and negligible toxicity for the VA-based ADC.
population_specificity: Preclinical study (xenograft model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an efficient screening method (96-PH) and improve L-valine production in Brevibacterium flavum MDV1 using genome shuffling.
results_summary: The study successfully increased L-valine production by 6.8-fold in shake flask fermentation (30.1 g/L) and achieved 70.1 g/L in fed-batch fermentation, demonstrating high yield and stability in industrial-scale production. The 96-PH screening method proved economical, rapid, and efficient for high-throughput strain selection.
population_specificity: Microbial strain (Brevibacterium flavum MDV1)
study_duration: Not specified (fermentation process duration not detailed)
